name: Afghanistan
currentCrisisSummary:
Since the US withdrawal and Taliban takeover in August 2021, Afghanistan endures widespread suffering driven by **economic collapse** and the dismantling of public services. This deep humanitarian emergency results directly from the freezing of central bank assets and broad financial restrictions imposed by Western powers, isolating the country and crippling its ability to function. Millions face acute food insecurity and malnutrition.

These **external economic pressures** â€” including the freezing of $7 billion in sovereign reserves â€” function as a form of **collective punishment**, drastically reducing state capacity and access to imports, with devastating consequences for health, food, and livelihoods. The situation reverses fragile, aid-dependent development gains and fuels mass displacement and poverty, particularly impacting women and minorities facing systematic exclusion.

The suffering is not merely an outcome of internal politics but is actively **sustained by international economic warfare**: asset freezes, sanctions, and financial exclusion have direct, measurable impacts. While immediate aid is vital, addressing the crisis requires challenging these external coercive measures and supporting genuinely Afghan-led recovery.

imperialRoot.imperialPower: Britain & Russian Empire (19th c. - 1919), USSR (1979-1989), US (2001-2021)
imperialRoot.legacy:
Afghanistan's contemporary fragility is embedded in a long history of foreign intervention. In the 19th century the 'Great Game' between the British and Russian empires reshaped frontier politics and weakened indigenous centres of authority. Soviet intervention (1979-1989) and the Cold War proxy struggles that preceded it precipitated decades of violent conflict and state collapse. The US intervention after 2001 created a hollow, aid-dependent rentier state. This nation-building project was fundamentally neoliberal, prioritising privatisation, outsourcing basic services to a vast network of foreign contractors and NGOs, and imposing a market-based model that fuelled systemic corruption and was unsustainable without massive external financing.

Each major intervention reshaped Afghan social, economic and political institutions, often entrenching dependency, fragmenting local governance and amplifying violent non-state actors. The repeated external remaking of Afghanistan has therefore been a structural driver of instability and humanitarian vulnerability.

historicalContext.title: The "Graveyard of Empires" Myth
historicalContext.description: The phrase 'graveyard of empires' is a trope that individualises failure and obscures the central role of sustained foreign interference. Successive imperial and great-power campaigns sought to reorder Afghan society and state institutions to serve external strategic aims â€” a process that frequently undermined local political autonomy and social cohesion. Rather than an inherent incapacity, much of Afghanistan's instability must be read as the product of repeated external interventions and extractive geopolitical competition.

historicalContext.title: The Opium Economy and the War on Drugs
historicalContext.description: The 20-year international presence operated alongside a massive opium economy. Western-led counter-narcotics strategies, framed as a 'war on drugs', consistently failed and had perverse effects: they criminalised impoverished farmers who lacked alternative livelihoods, enriched corrupt officials and warlords involved in trafficking, and functioned as another misguided external policy that destabilised rural society while ignoring the root causes of poppy cultivation.

historicalContext.title: Economic Pressure and Sanctions
historicalContext.description:
After August 2021 international financial measures â€” notably the freezing of roughly $7 billion in central bank reserves held overseas and restrictions on formal banking relations â€” have constrained Afghanistan's ability to import, pay salaries and deliver public services. Multilateral and unilateral sanctions, plus restrictive de-risking by international banks and donors' conditionalities, have contributed to economic contraction, spiralling unemployment, and a sharp deterioration in living standards. Many analysts and humanitarian actors argue that these measures, as they have been applied, function as forms of economic coercion that disproportionately punish civilians and limit humanitarian space.

These pressures have compounded the impacts of climate shocks, conflict and displacement, producing one of the largest humanitarian crises in the world today.

historicalContext.title: International Law and Accountability
historicalContext.description: While the post-2021 context raises urgent humanitarian questions, there are also accountability dimensions connected to earlier interventions and the conduct of armed actors. Investigations, reporting and academic research have documented violations and long-term harm associated with successive periods of foreign military action, proxy support and state collapse. Although formal international accountability mechanisms have been limited or contested, documenting abuses and supporting Afghan civil society and survivors remains essential for redress and longer-term justice.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands killed directly by conflict since 2001; far more suffer **indirect deaths** caused by the collapse of healthcare and widespread malnutrition resulting from war and economic blockade.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 23.7 million people endure conditions requiring humanitarian aid due to the **compounded effects of war, sanctions, and state collapse.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Around 15.8 million people face crisis-level food insecurity, a direct result of **economic strangulation, aid dependency, and climate shocks.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 6.3 million internally displaced by decades of **foreign intervention, resulting conflict, economic pressures, and climate breakdown.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: More than 8.2 million Afghans forced into refugee situations by **chronic instability generated by external interference and internal conflict.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Thousands of health facilities non-functional due to **funding cuts directly linked to international financial restrictions and the legacy of an aid-dependent system.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Deepening Poverty
humanitarianImpact.description: Extreme poverty surged after 2021, with tens of millions suffering **deep economic insecurity inflicted by sanctions and the implosion of the foreign-funded economy.**

timeline.event: **The Great Game**: A century of imperial rivalry between the British and Russian empires reshapes Afghan frontiers and politics, with three Anglo-Afghan wars and repeated interventions that undermine indigenous political autonomy.

**Independence, Modernisation and Interference**: Afghanistan achieves formal independence in 1919 but experiences recurring foreign influence and internal contestation as attempts to centralise and modernise are mediated by regional and imperial pressures.
**The Saur Revolution**: A coup brings the PDPA to power; radical social reforms and violent repression provoke widespread unrest.
**Soviet Invasion and Occupation**: The USSR intervenes militarily to support the PDPA, triggering a decade of war that causes mass death, displacement and the destruction of infrastructure.

**US Covert Support for Mujahideen**: The CIA's Operation Cyclone funds and arms insurgent groups resisting Soviet forces; this proxy warfare has long-term consequences for militancy and state collapse.
**Taliban First Rule**: The Taliban seize Kabul after civil war and impose a repressive regime that severely curtails rights, especially for women and girls.

**US Invasion & Occupation**: Following 9/11 the US and coalition forces overthrow the Taliban and initiate a two-decade intervention that channels vast resources into security, contracting and technocratic projects that deepen dependence on foreign aid and military spending.
**US Withdrawal & Taliban Return**: The chaotic US withdrawal in August 2021 precipitates the rapid collapse of the internationally backed government and the return of the Taliban to national power.

**Economic Warfare & Humanitarian Catastrophe**: International asset freezes and sanctions function as economic warfare, triggering state collapse and causing a deepening humanitarian catastrophe affecting tens of millions.

donate.description: A British humanitarian and development organisation working with deprived and excluded communities across Afghanistan.
Provides protection and assistance to refugees, returnees and internally displaced people from and within Afghanistan.
Focuses on providing education and protection for children, particularly girls, whose lives have been impacted by conflict and the economic crisis.
Delivers emergency food and nutrition support to communities across Afghanistan and is critical in preventing famine.

advocacy: Amplify Afghan civil society voices, especially women's rights activists, journalists and human-rights defenders.
Support Afghan-led organisations delivering aid and protection on the ground, and demand funding channels that enable direct, accountable transfers to local partners.
Advocate for the unfreezing or conditional, accountable release of sovereign assets to ensure civilians can access essential imports, salaries and public services.
Push for safe and legal routes for refugees and for humanitarian exemptions to sanctions that impede life-saving assistance.
Demand transparency and accountability for the costs and consequences of decades of foreign interventions and profiteering.

reading.title: Ghost Wars: The Secret History of the CIA, Afghanistan, and Bin Laden, from the Soviet Invasion to September 10, 2001
reading.description: Steve Coll's investigative account of US covert operations and their longer-term effects in Afghanistan.

reading.title: No Good Men Among the Living: America, the Taliban, and the War Through Afghan Eyes
reading.description: Anand Gopal's reporting on ordinary Afghans' experiences of war, occupation and the post-2001 political order.

reading.title: The Afghanistan Papers: A Secret History of the War
reading.description: Craig Whitlock uses confidential documents to expose the systemic failures and deceptions of the 20-year US war effort.
